{"aid": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2504.11061v1", "title": "Synthesis and characterization of gold-coated nanodiamonds through green
  chemistry as potential radiosensitizers for proton therapy", "summary": "In this work the synthesis and characterization of novel gold-nanodiamond
nanoparticles was performed. The synthesis was based on the reduction of gold
onto the different types of nanodiamond (annealed or annealed and oxidized, 50
or 230 nm) using root extracts of Nympheaea alba as a reducing agent. These
gold-coated nanodiamonds were characterized by UV-Vis, PXRD, DLS,
zeta-potential, PIXE, Raman, SEM, and TEM, assessing particle size, stability,
and gold coating effectiveness. Cellular studies in the A549 and Panc1 cancer
cell lines assessed uptake, cytotoxicity, and colony formation to evaluate
NDAu's biological activity. NDAu demonstrated strong cellular uptake and
cytotoxic effects in A549 and Panc1 cell lines, reducing cell survival in
clonogenic assay. Futher research in the capabilites of these nanoparticles for
proton therapy will be performed.", "main_category": "hep-ex", "categories": "hep-ex,cond-mat.mtrl-sci", "published": "2025-04-15T10:49:51Z"}
